elements.content: Two extended Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalate-based inorganic–organic hybrid materials exhibiting anion-induced supramolecular isomerism were reported. Because of the cis–trans isomerism in the octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, the Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalates are extended by double O–Co–O bridges in 1α and a single O–Co–O bridge in 1β to form the isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks, respectively. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.
elements.clean_text: Two extended Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalate-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials exhibiting anion-induced supramolecular isomerism were reported. Because of the cis-trans isomerism in the octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, the Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalates are extended by double O-Co-O bridges in 1α and a single O-Co-O bridge in 1β to form the isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks, respectively. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.

elements.content: Two extended Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalate-based inorganic−organic hybrid materials exhibiting anion-induced supramolecular isomerism were reported. Because of the cis−trans isomerism in the octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, the Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalates are extended by double O−Co−O bridges in 1α and a single O−Co−O bridge in 1β to form the isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks, respectively. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.
elements.clean_text: Two extended Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalate-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials exhibiting anion-induced supramolecular isomerism were reported. Because of the cis-trans isomerism in the octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, the Preyssler P5W30 polyoxometalates are extended by double O-Co-O bridges in 1α and a single O-Co-O bridge in 1β to form the isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks, respectively. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are eye-catching inorganic secondary building blocks (ISBBs) for constructing diverse hybrid materials. They do not merely supply substantial basic O atoms as polydentate inorganic linkers, but show various chemical compositions, dimensions, and geometric shapes as well as rich physical and chemical properties. In this field, incorporation of 3d transition metal ions to decorate POMs could change their topological structures and properties. However, compared to much work on the decoration of small POMs (the number of W or Mo in one cluster < 20) to extended networks, larger POMs, such as the Preyssler POM, {P5W30}, which comprises five PW6 subunits and totally 90 O atoms covered on the shell (30 μ1-O and 60 μ2-O), are less investigated as ISBBs. Although it has many superiorities, including (i) high acid or base stability over a wide pH range of 1–10; (ii) more surface oxygen atoms and high negative charges to bind more transition metal ions; and (iii) its internal cavity with a diameter of about 5 Å can accommodate distinct cations with proper diameters, until now, only sporadic examples including some discrete metal-centered Preyssler clusters and extended Preyssler clusters by external decoration have appeared in literature. With these regards, to create infinite Preyssler POMs-related hybrid frameworks appeared to be a fairly difficult task.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs) are eye-catching inorganic secondary building blocks (ISBBs) for constructing diverse hybrid materials. They do not merely supply substantial basic O atoms as polydentate inorganic linkers, but show various chemical compositions, dimensions, and geometric shapes as well as rich physical and chemical properties. In this field, incorporation of 3d transition metal ions to decorate POMs could change their topological structures and properties. However, compared to much work on the decoration of small POMs (the number of W or Mo in one cluster < 20) to extended networks, larger POMs, such as the Preyssler POM, {P5W30}, which comprises five PW6 subunits and totally 90 O atoms covered on the shell (30 μ1-O and 60 μ2-O), are less investigated as ISBBs. Although it has many superiorities, including (i) high acid or base stability over a wide pH range of 1-10; (ii) more surface oxygen atoms and high negative charges to bind more transition metal ions; and (iii) its internal cavity with a diameter of about 5 Å can accommodate distinct cations with proper diameters, until now, only sporadic examples including some discrete metal-centered Preyssler clusters and extended Preyssler clusters by external decoration have appeared in literature. With these regards, to create infinite Preyssler POMs-related hybrid frameworks appeared to be a fairly difficult task.

elements.content: On the other hand, supramolecular isomerism is an appealing phenomenon in supramolecular and coordination chemistry. With the ever-increasing appearance of publications about supramolecular isomerism, supramolecular isomerism in polymeric network structures becomes not too surprising; however, supramolecular isomerism was hard to be observed in POM-based hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, supramolecular isomerism is an appealing phenomenon in supramolecular and coordination chemistry. With the ever-increasing appearance of publications about supramolecular isomerism, supramolecular isomerism in polymeric network structures becomes not too surprising; however, supramolecular isomerism was hard to be observed in POM-based hybrid materials.

elements.content: Herein, we first report on a pair of anion-induced supramolecular isomers incorporating the cis–trans isomerism of the octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center (Scheme ), which is responsible for the resultant isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks with the formulas of {Co4(dimb)4­(H2O)8­[K(H2O)­H6P5W30­O110]} n (1α·122H2O and 1β·90H2O; dimb = 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzene), respectively.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we first report on a pair of anion-induced supramolecular isomers incorporating the cis-trans isomerism of the octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center (Scheme ), which is responsible for the resultant isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks with the formulas of {Co4(dimb)4(H2O)8[K(H2O)H6P5W30O110]} n  (1α⋅122H2O and 1β⋅90H2O; dimb = 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene), respectively.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAT FT-IR360 spectrometer as KBr pellets in the frequency range of 4000–400 cm–1. The elemental analyses (C, H, N contents) were determined on a Vario EL III analyzer. Elemental analyses of K, P, W, and Co were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Philips X’Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation equipped with an X’Celerator detector. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of solid samples were recorded on a Bruker X-band EPR spectrometer equipped with a temperature controller. Electrochemical measurements were performed with a CHI660 electrochemical workstation. A conventional three-electrode system was used. The working electrode was a modified carbon paste electrode (CPE). A Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode was used as a reference electrode and a Pt wire as a counter electrode.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAT FT-IR360 spectrometer as KBr pellets in the frequency range of 4000-400 cm-1. The elemental analyses (C, H, N contents) were determined on a Vario EL III analyzer. Elemental analyses of K, P, W, and Co were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Philips X'Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation equipped with an X'Celerator detector. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of solid samples were recorded on a Bruker X-band EPR spectrometer equipped with a temperature controller. Electrochemical measurements were performed with a CHI660 electrochemical workstation. A conventional three-electrode system was used. The working electrode was a modified carbon paste electrode (CPE). A Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode was used as a reference electrode and a Pt wire as a counter electrode.

elements.content: A mixture of K12.5Na1.5­[NaP5W30­O110]·​15H2O (82.4 mg, 0.01 mmol), 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzene (10.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·​6H2O (43.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of H2O and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min, after which, it was cooled over 13 h to room temperature. The product was obtained as pink rodlike crystals in 40% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H284­Co4KN16O241­P5W30: C, 5.30 (5.68); H, 2.63 (2.58); N, 2.06 (2.30); P, 1.42 (1.85); K, 0.36 (0.22); Co, 2.17 (2.86); W, 50.66 (50.24) %.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex 1α 

A mixture of K12.5Na1.5[NaP5W30O110]⋅15H2O (82.4 mg, 0.01 mmol), 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene (10.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (43.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of H2O and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min, after which, it was cooled over 13 h to room temperature. The product was obtained as pink rodlike crystals in 40% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H284Co4KN16O241P5W30: C, 5.30 (5.68); H, 2.63 (2.58); N, 2.06 (2.30); P, 1.42 (1.85); K, 0.36 (0.22); Co, 2.17 (2.86); W, 50.66 (50.24) %.

elements.content: The synthesis of 1β was similar to that of 1α, but using CoCl2·​6H2O (35.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of Co(NO3)2·​6H2O. The product was obtained as mixed pink rodlike (1α) and yellow block-shaped crystals (1β), which are separated manually, giving 1β in 25% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H220­Co4KN16O209­P5W30: C, 5.59 (5.55); H, 2.15 (2.87); N, 2.17 (2.01); P, 1.50 (1.96); K, 0.38 (0.26); Co, 2.29 (2.75); W, 53.49 (53.12) %
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex 1β 

The synthesis of 1β was similar to that of 1α, but using CoCl2⋅6H2O (35.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. The product was obtained as mixed pink rodlike (1α) and yellow block-shaped crystals (1β), which are separated manually, giving 1β in 25% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H220Co4KN16O209P5W30: C, 5.59 (5.55); H, 2.15 (2.87); N, 2.17 (2.01); P, 1.50 (1.96); K, 0.38 (0.26); Co, 2.29 (2.75); W, 53.49 (53.12) %

elements.content: 1α and 1β are found to crystallize in face- and body-centered orthorhombic lattices with space groups of Fmmm and Immm, respectively, by X-ray single-crystal crystallographic analysis (Table ). There are one-eighth of [K(H2O)­H6P5W30­O110]8– and a half of a [Co(dimb)­(H2O)2]2+ unit in their asymmetric units. The valences of W (+6) and Co (+2) atoms were verified by bond valence sum (BVS) calculations. The Preyssler-type P5W30 POM is the same in 1α and 1β, and five PO4 3– ions in the interior support the tire-like W30 shell. The 5-fold passes through the central axis of the W30 tire, giving it a perfect 5-fold symmetry. Five P atoms are in a mirror plane perpendicular to the central axis. Among 30 W atoms, 20 are distributed on the two treads and the remaining 10 are on the two sidewalls of the tire: each of the sidewall and tread contains 5 and 10 W atoms, respectively. All W centers are coordinated by six O atoms, forming the WO6 octahedron. The bond distances between W and O in 1α and 1β are 1.67(4)–1.79(3) and 1.702(14)–1.74(2) Å for μ1-O atoms, 1.80(3)–2.011(13) and 1.850(12)–2.036(9) Å for μ2-O atoms, and 2.209(14)–2.308(18) and 2.21(2)–2.264(12) Å for μ3-O atoms, respectively, which are comparable to the related compounds. The Na ion is not presented in the central cavity of 1α and 1β, but replaced by K ion, which is a common phenomenon and also proved by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The outer Co(II) center is surrounded by four O atoms, two from POM and the other two from aqua, and two imidazole N atoms, giving an octahedral geometry. As illustrated in Figure a,b, eight Co(II) centers (four “above” and four “below”) in total are anchored onto each P5W30 POM via eight terminal oxygen atoms distributed in two inner W10 planes in two isomers. Although the P5W30 anion has up to 30 terminal O atoms accessible to form coordination bonds with metal centers, not all of them could bind metal centers due to electronic and steric hindrance effects.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Descriptions of 1α and 1β 

 1α and 1β are found to crystallize in face- and body-centered orthorhombic lattices with space groups of Fmmm and Immm, respectively, by X-ray single-crystal crystallographic analysis (Table ). There are one-eighth of [K(H2O)H6P5W30O110]8- and a half of a [Co(dimb)(H2O)2]2+ unit in their asymmetric units. The valences of W (+6) and Co (+2) atoms were verified by bond valence sum (BVS) calculations. The Preyssler-type P5W30 POM is the same in 1α and 1β, and five PO4 3- ions in the interior support the tire-like W30 shell. The 5-fold passes through the central axis of the W30 tire, giving it a perfect 5-fold symmetry. Five P atoms are in a mirror plane perpendicular to the central axis. Among 30 W atoms, 20 are distributed on the two treads and the remaining 10 are on the two sidewalls of the tire: each of the sidewall and tread contains 5 and 10 W atoms, respectively. All W centers are coordinated by six O atoms, forming the WO6 octahedron. The bond distances between W and O in 1α and 1β are 1.67(4)-1.79(3) and 1.702(14)-1.74(2) Å for μ1-O atoms, 1.80(3)-2.011(13) and 1.850(12)-2.036(9) Å for μ2-O atoms, and 2.209(14)-2.308(18) and 2.21(2)-2.264(12) Å for μ3-O atoms, respectively, which are comparable to the related compounds. The Na ion is not presented in the central cavity of 1α and 1β, but replaced by K ion, which is a common phenomenon and also proved by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The outer Co(II) center is surrounded by four O atoms, two from POM and the other two from aqua, and two imidazole N atoms, giving an octahedral geometry. As illustrated in Figure a,b, eight Co(II) centers (four "above" and four "below") in total are anchored onto each P5W30 POM via eight terminal oxygen atoms distributed in two inner W10 planes in two isomers. Although the P5W30 anion has up to 30 terminal O atoms accessible to form coordination bonds with metal centers, not all of them could bind metal centers due to electronic and steric hindrance effects.

Views of molecular structures and coordination details of cobalt(II) centers in 1α (a) and 1β (b). The cis (c) and trans (d) octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center in 1α and 1β.
elements.clean_text: 1  Views of molecular structures and coordination details of cobalt(II) centers in 1α (a) and 1β (b). The cis (c) and trans (d) octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center in 1α and 1β.

elements.content: The most different structural feature in 1α and 1β is the cis–trans isomeric octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center, as represented in Figure c,d. The broad electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra (Figure S1, ) feature from 20 to 380 mT unambiguously indicates the presence of the high spin Co(II) (S = 3/2, d 7) at 40 K, and the differences in EPR also confirm the dissimilar coordinated atom arrangement around the Co(II) centers in 1α and 1β, which ultimately caused the Preyssler P5W30 POMs in 1α and 1β to be extended to form isomeric 2D and 3D networks, respectively. For 1α, each Preyssler P5W30 POM is linked to its one neighbor (totally four neighbors) through double O–Co–O bridges (Figure a,b), so it becomes a 4-connected node, despite that each P5W30 links eight Co(II) centers. As a result, the 2D 4-connected 44-sql network (Figure c) along the ab plane formed in 1α. Differently, in 1β, each Preyssler P5W30 POM is linked to its one neighbor (totally eight neighbors) through a single O–Co–O bridge (Figure d,e), and so it retains an 8-connected node. As a result, the 3D 8-connected bcu network (Figure f) formed in 1β. In fact, each dimb as a bidentate ligand clamps a pair of Co(II) centers anchored on the same one P5W30 POM in 1α and 1β, so it contributes nothing to the extension of the P5W30-based networks. However, due to cis or trans arrangement of the dimb ligand around the Co(II) centers, steric requirements dictate the linkage between adjacent P5W30 POMs through a double or single O–Co–O bridge, thus determining the resultant networks.
elements.clean_text: The most different structural feature in 1α and 1β is the cis-trans isomeric octahedral coordination geometry around the Co(II) center, as represented in Figure c,d. The broad electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra (Figure S1, ) feature from 20 to 380 mT unambiguously indicates the presence of the high spin Co(II) (S = 3/2, d 7) at 40 K, and the differences in EPR also confirm the dissimilar coordinated atom arrangement around the Co(II) centers in 1α and 1β, which ultimately caused the Preyssler P5W30 POMs in 1α and 1β to be extended to form isomeric 2D and 3D networks, respectively. For 1α, each Preyssler P5W30 POM is linked to its one neighbor (totally four neighbors) through double O-Co-O bridges (Figure a,b), so it becomes a 4-connected node, despite that each P5W30 links eight Co(II) centers. As a result, the 2D 4-connected 44-sql network (Figure c) along the ab plane formed in 1α. Differently, in 1β, each Preyssler P5W30 POM is linked to its one neighbor (totally eight neighbors) through a single O-Co-O bridge (Figure d,e), and so it retains an 8-connected node. As a result, the 3D 8-connected bcu network (Figure f) formed in 1β. In fact, each dimb as a bidentate ligand clamps a pair of Co(II) centers anchored on the same one P5W30 POM in 1α and 1β, so it contributes nothing to the extension of the P5W30-based networks. However, due to cis or trans arrangement of the dimb ligand around the Co(II) centers, steric requirements dictate the linkage between adjacent P5W30 POMs through a double or single O-Co-O bridge, thus determining the resultant networks.

elements.content: (a) P5W30 POM linked to its four neighbors through four double O–Co–O bridges in 1α. (b) The linkage mode between two adjacent P5W30 POMs in 1α. (c) The simplified 2D 44-sql network of 1α. (d) P5W30 POM linked to its eight neighbors through eight single O–Co–O bridges in 1β. (e) The linkage mode between two adjacent P5W30 POMs in 1β. (f) The simplified 3D 8-connected bcu network of 1β.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) P5W30 POM linked to its four neighbors through four double O-Co-O bridges in 1α. (b) The linkage mode between two adjacent P5W30 POMs in 1α. (c) The simplified 2D 44-sql network of 1α. (d) P5W30 POM linked to its eight neighbors through eight single O-Co-O bridges in 1β. (e) The linkage mode between two adjacent P5W30 POMs in 1β. (f) The simplified 3D 8-connected bcu network of 1β.

elements.content: The 1α was obtained as a single phase using Co(NO3)2·​6H2O, whereas concomitant crystallization of 1α and 1β occurred when using CoCl2·​6H2O, so it would be of interest to see if the predominant formation of 1β could be induced by adding much more Cl– ions. When different amounts of NaCl were deliberately added during synthesis of 1α, both 1α and 1β still appeared in the final products, but the quality percentage of 1β increased with the amount of NaCl in the range of 0.1–2.0 mmol. Further increasing the amount of NaCl could not give a higher yield of 1β (max. 87%). (Figure ). These results clearly showed the obvious induced effect of the Cl– anion on the formation of supramolecular isomer, 1β. Although both NO3 – and Cl– did not participate in the resultant networks, they exerted different bonding abilities and orientations toward the Co(II) ion at the beginning of the self-assembly in the solutions, which may affect the subsequent bonding directions of the organic linker and Preyssler P5W30 POMs, causing the occurrence of the supramolecular isomerism in this system.
elements.clean_text:
Induced Effect of the Anions

The 1α was obtained as a single phase using Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, whereas concomitant crystallization of 1α and 1β occurred when using CoCl2⋅6H2O, so it would be of interest to see if the predominant formation of 1β could be induced by adding much more Cl- ions. When different amounts of NaCl were deliberately added during synthesis of 1α, both 1α and 1β still appeared in the final products, but the quality percentage of 1β increased with the amount of NaCl in the range of 0.1-2.0 mmol. Further increasing the amount of NaCl could not give a higher yield of 1β (max. 87%). (Figure ). These results clearly showed the obvious induced effect of the Cl- anion on the formation of supramolecular isomer, 1β. Although both NO3 - and Cl- did not participate in the resultant networks, they exerted different bonding abilities and orientations toward the Co(II) ion at the beginning of the self-assembly in the solutions, which may affect the subsequent bonding directions of the organic linker and Preyssler P5W30 POMs, causing the occurrence of the supramolecular isomerism in this system.

elements.content: Plot of quality percentage of 1β vs amount of NaCl.
elements.clean_text: 3  Plot of quality percentage of 1β vs amount of NaCl.

elements.content: The electrochemical behaviors of 1α and 1β were studied in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution at changing scanning speed. As depicted in Figure a,b, from −1.0 to 1.0 V, three pairs of reversible peaks related to oxidation–reduction reactions are detected for 1α- and 1β-CPE. The average peak potentials E 1/2 = 0.5(E pa + E pc) of I/I′, II/II′, and III/III′ are −0.56, −0.12, and +0.51 V for 1α-CPE as well as −0.54, −0.29, and +0.47 V, for 1β-CPE (on account of the cyclic voltammogram at 100 mV s–1 shown in Figure S2, ). Two pairs of redox peaks, II/II′ and III/III′, for 1α- and 1β-CPE are attributed to two successive double electron processes of the modified {P5W30} polyoxoanion. Redox peaks I–I′ in the positive directions for 1α- and 1β-CPE should be ascribed to the redox couple of CoIII/CoII. The differences in the peak positions between the parent {P5W30} and 1α and 1β are attributed to the incorporation of the Co(II) ions, whereas the different coordination environments around Co(II) in 1α and 1β cause their different redox performance. The cathodic peaks of 1α and 1β move to the lower potentials, whereas the corresponding anodic peaks move to the higher potentials when enhancing scanning speed, as depicted in Figure . When the scanning speed increased from 20 to 500 mV s–1, the peak potentials also vary progressively. Furthermore, although the increase of the separation between the paired oxidative and reductive peaks was clearly discriminated, the mean peak potentials are basically maintained as a whole. The plotting of peak current (II) of anode and cathode versus scanning speed (see inset plots in Figure a,b) suggests that the redox processes of 1α- and 1β-CPE that occurred on the surface are populated when the scanning speed is lower than 100 mV s–1, whereas, at a scanning speed higher than 100 mV s–1, the peak currents were proportional to the square root of the scanning speed, indicating the diffusion-controlled redox processes. It is also of note that 1α- and 1β-CPE are highly stable. When the range of potential is sustained between −1.0 and 1.0 V, the peak currents remain almost unaffected over 300 cycles at a scanning speed of 100 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text:
Voltammetric Behavior of 1α- and 1β-CPEs

The electrochemical behaviors of 1α and 1β were studied in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution at changing scanning speed. As depicted in Figure a,b, from -1.0 to 1.0 V, three pairs of reversible peaks related to oxidation-reduction reactions are detected for 1α- and 1β-CPE. The average peak potentials E 1/2 = 0.5(E pa + E pc) of I/I', II/II', and III/III' are -0.56, -0.12, and +0.51 V for 1α-CPE as well as -0.54, -0.29, and +0.47 V, for 1β-CPE (on account of the cyclic voltammogram at 100 mV s-1 shown in Figure S2, ). Two pairs of redox peaks, II/II' and III/III', for 1α- and 1β-CPE are attributed to two successive double electron processes of the modified {P5W30} polyoxoanion. Redox peaks I-I' in the positive directions for 1α- and 1β-CPE should be ascribed to the redox couple of CoIII/CoII. The differences in the peak positions between the parent {P5W30} and 1α and 1β are attributed to the incorporation of the Co(II) ions, whereas the different coordination environments around Co(II) in 1α and 1β cause their different redox performance. The cathodic peaks of 1α and 1β move to the lower potentials, whereas the corresponding anodic peaks move to the higher potentials when enhancing scanning speed, as depicted in Figure . When the scanning speed increased from 20 to 500 mV s-1, the peak potentials also vary progressively. Furthermore, although the increase of the separation between the paired oxidative and reductive peaks was clearly discriminated, the mean peak potentials are basically maintained as a whole. The plotting of peak current (II) of anode and cathode versus scanning speed (see inset plots in Figure a,b) suggests that the redox processes of 1α- and 1β-CPE that occurred on the surface are populated when the scanning speed is lower than 100 mV s-1, whereas, at a scanning speed higher than 100 mV s-1, the peak currents were proportional to the square root of the scanning speed, indicating the diffusion-controlled redox processes. It is also of note that 1α- and 1β-CPE are highly stable. When the range of potential is sustained between -1.0 and 1.0 V, the peak currents remain almost unaffected over 300 cycles at a scanning speed of 100 mV s-1.

elements.content: (a, b) Cyclic voltammograms of the 1α- and 1β-CPEs in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution at different scanning speeds (from inside to outside: 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 80, 100, 120, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, 500 mV s–1). Inset: The plotting of peak current (II) of anode and cathode versus scanning speed. (c, d) Cyclic voltammograms of the 1α- and 1β-CPEs in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution containing 0.0, 5.0, 10.0, and 15.0 mmol/L H2O2 with a scanning speed of 40 mV/s.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a, b) Cyclic voltammograms of the 1α- and 1β-CPEs in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution at different scanning speeds (from inside to outside: 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 80, 100, 120, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, 500 mV s-1). Inset: The plotting of peak current (II) of anode and cathode versus scanning speed. (c, d) Cyclic voltammograms of the 1α- and 1β-CPEs in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid aqueous solution containing 0.0, 5.0, 10.0, and 15.0 mmol/L H2O2 with a scanning speed of 40 mV/s.

elements.content: Furthermore, 1α- and 1β-CPE show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2 (Figure c,d). At the 1α- and 1β-CPE, with the increase of the concentration of H2O2 from 0.0 to 15.0 mmol/L, increase of reduction peak currents and at the same time, the decrease of the corresponding oxidation peak currents were observed, indicating that H2O2 was reduced by two species of P5W30 polyoxoanion. For comparison, the electroreduction of H2O2 at a naked electrode usually needs a high overpotential and no noticeable response could be detected at a bare CPE. The results demonstrate that 1α- and 1β-CPEs have electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.
elements.clean_text:
Electrocatalytic Activity of 1α- and 1β-CPEs for the Reduction of H2O2 

Furthermore, 1α- and 1β-CPE show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2 (Figure c,d). At the 1α- and 1β-CPE, with the increase of the concentration of H2O2 from 0.0 to 15.0 mmol/L, increase of reduction peak currents and at the same time, the decrease of the corresponding oxidation peak currents were observed, indicating that H2O2 was reduced by two species of P5W30 polyoxoanion. For comparison, the electroreduction of H2O2 at a naked electrode usually needs a high overpotential and no noticeable response could be detected at a bare CPE. The results demonstrate that 1α- and 1β-CPEs have electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.

elements.content: In conclusion, 1α and 1β represent the first examples of supramolecular isomeric Preyssler P5W30-based inorganic–organic hybrids depended on different anions. The supramolecular isomerism originated from the cis–trans octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, which causes isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks to be obtained. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, 1α and 1β represent the first examples of supramolecular isomeric Preyssler P5W30-based inorganic-organic hybrids depended on different anions. The supramolecular isomerism originated from the cis-trans octahedral CoN2O4 coordination geometry, which causes isomeric 2D 4-connected 44-sql and 3D 8-connected bcu networks to be obtained. Both compounds show electrocatalytic abilities on the reduction of H2O2.

elements.content: Synthesis procedure, tables, crystal data in CIF files, EPR, IR, CV, TGA, and powder X-ray diffractogram for 1α and 1β (CCDC 1008983–1008984). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis procedure, tables, crystal data in CIF files, EPR, IR, CV, TGA, and powder X-ray diffractogram for 1α and 1β (CCDC 1008983-1008984). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of K12.5Na1.5­[NaP5W30­O110]·​15H2O (82.4 mg, 0.01 mmol), 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzene (10.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·​6H2O (43.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of H2O and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min, after which, it was cooled over 13 h to room temperature. The product was obtained as pink rodlike crystals in 40% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H284­Co4KN16O241­P5W30: C, 5.30 (5.68); H, 2.63 (2.58); N, 2.06 (2.30); P, 1.42 (1.85); K, 0.36 (0.22); Co, 2.17 (2.86); W, 50.66 (50.24) %.

Synthesis of Complex <bold>1β</bold>

The synthesis of 1β was similar to that of 1α, but using CoCl2·​6H2O (35.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of Co(NO3)2·​6H2O. The product was obtained as mixed pink rodlike (1α) and yellow block-shaped crystals (1β), which are separated manually, giving 1β in 25% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H220­Co4KN16O209­P5W30: C, 5.59 (5.55); H, 2.15 (2.87); N, 2.17 (2.01); P, 1.50 (1.96); K, 0.38 (0.26); Co, 2.29 (2.75); W, 53.49 (53.12) %
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex 1α 

A mixture of K12.5Na1.5[NaP5W30O110]⋅15H2O (82.4 mg, 0.01 mmol), 1,3-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene (10.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (43.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of H2O and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min, after which, it was cooled over 13 h to room temperature. The product was obtained as pink rodlike crystals in 40% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H284Co4KN16O241P5W30: C, 5.30 (5.68); H, 2.63 (2.58); N, 2.06 (2.30); P, 1.42 (1.85); K, 0.36 (0.22); Co, 2.17 (2.86); W, 50.66 (50.24) %.

Synthesis of Complex 1β 

The synthesis of 1β was similar to that of 1α, but using CoCl2⋅6H2O (35.7 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. The product was obtained as mixed pink rodlike (1α) and yellow block-shaped crystals (1β), which are separated manually, giving 1β in 25% yield (based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd. (found) for C48H220Co4KN16O209P5W30: C, 5.59 (5.55); H, 2.15 (2.87); N, 2.17 (2.01); P, 1.50 (1.96); K, 0.38 (0.26); Co, 2.29 (2.75); W, 53.49 (53.12) %
